awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Multilevel Mediation Models to Study the Impact of Teacher Development on Student Achievement in Mathematics
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a Faculty Early Career Development Program (CAREER) project. The CAREER program is a National Science Foundation-wide activity that offers the most prestigious awards in support of junior faculty who exemplify the role of teacher-scholars through outstanding research, excellent education and the integration of education and research. The intellectual merit and broader impacts of this study lie in two complementary contributions of the project. First, the development of the statistical framework for the design of multilevel mediation studies has significant potential for broad impact because it develops a core platform that is transferable to other STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) education areas and STEM disciplines. Second, the development of software and curricular materials to implement this framework further capitalize on the promise of this work because it distributes the results in an accessible manner to diverse sets of research and practitioner groups across STEM education areas and STEM disciplines. Together, the components of this project will substantially expand the scope and quality of evidence generated through mathematics professional development and, more generally, multilevel mediation studies throughout STEM areas by increasing researchers' capacity to design valid and comprehensive studies of the theories of action and change that underlie research programs.

This project will develop a comprehensive framework to inform and guide the analytic design of teacher professional development studies in mathematics. The proposed framework incorporates four integrated research and education components: (1) develop statistical formulas and tools to guide the optimal design of experimental and non-experimental multilevel mediation studies in the presence of measurement error, (2) develop empirical estimates of the parameters needed to implement these formulas to design teacher development studies in mathematics, (3) develop free and accessible software to execute this framework, and (4) develop training materials and conduct workshops on the framework to improve the capacity of the field to design effective and efficient studies of teacher development. An essential goal of the research is to advance a science of teaching and learning in ways that traverse both research and education.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
Teacher professional development is critical to improving the quality of schooling and student growth. Despite sustained interest and investment in growing and improving teachers, prior research has not developed durable statistical and empirical frameworks to guide the design and analysis of teacher professional development studies. In this study, we addressed this gap by establishing statistical methods, empirical evidence, tools and software to guide the design and analysis of studies probing mathematics teacher development. The project produced four complementary facets of research. First, the project developed statistical theory to guide the design and analysis of teacher development studies. Second, the project developed empirical estimates of the core parameter values that govern the effective and efficient design of teacher development studies. Third, the project produced accessible statistical software implementing the results. Fourth, the project implemented a broad range of workshops to disseminate the findings and train researchers in the application of the framework and the software.

The work conducted in this project contributed to the larger advancement of science in two ways. First, the study addressed a critical methodological gap in STEM education research by developing frameworks and tools that are well-attuned to the core features of teacher professional development research. In turn, the methods, empirical evidence, software and training have collectively improved the capacity of the field to conduct rigorous and well-planned studies and expanded and the scope and quality of evidence generated through studies probing STEM teacher development. Second, although the tools developed in this study build capacity in mathematics education, the results and software are broadly applicable and transferrable to other STEM research and disciplines. The gap between the complexity found in teacher professional development studies and the prevailing methods we use to design and analyze those studies is not unique to mathematics education. Rather, a critical constraint across much STEM education and research and many other disciplines is the limitations of conventional methods in the empirical design and analysis of complex theories.


Last Modified: 12/01/2023
Modified by: Benjamin Kelcey
